questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a unit for centripetal acceleration?
questions.explanation: $\text{rad/s}^2$ is angular acceleration, not linear acceleration. $\text{N/kg} = \text{m/s}^2$, so it is a valid unit.

questions.question: A car travels at $20 \text{ m/s}$ around a curve with a radius of $50 \text{ m}$. What is its centripetal acceleration?
An object is whirled in a circle of radius $2 \text{ m}$ with a tangential speed of $10 \text{ m/s}$. Calculate $a_c$.
A centrifuge has a radius of $0.1 \text{ m}$. If the centripetal acceleration is $1000 \text{ m/s}^2$, what is the tangential speed?
A point on a rotating wheel is $0.5 \text{ m}$ from the center and completes one revolution every $2 \text{ seconds}$. What is its centripetal acceleration?
Centripetal acceleration is perpendicular to:
questions.explanation: Centripetal acceleration is radial (toward center), velocity is tangent, so they are perpendicular.

questions.question: Using period $T$, centripetal acceleration can be expressed as:
In non-uniform circular motion, there exists:
questions.explanation: Non-uniform circular motion has changing speed (tangential acceleration) and changing direction (centripetal acceleration).

questions.question: A 500 kg car rounds a curve of radius 40 meters at a constant speed of 15 meters per second. What is the car's centripetal acceleration?
A 0.5 kg object is whirled in a horizontal circle of radius 1.2 meters, completing one revolution every 0.8 seconds. What is its centripetal acceleration?
